isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION CARRIERS: ROCKWELL - REASSEMBLE - CHECK TOOTH CONTACT PATTERNS OF THE GEAR SET

svcproc.title: CHECK TOOTH CONTACT PATTERNS OF THE GEAR SET

svcsubproc.title: General Information
svcsubproc.para: Carriers can have a conventional hypoid gear set or a GENEROID hypoid gear set. The tooth contact patterns for each type of gear set are different. Look at the part numbers to see what type of gear set is in the carrier. See Figure 113 for the location of part numbers.
Examples of part numbers for conventional gear sets.
Examples of part numbers for GENEROID gear sets.
In the following procedures, movement of the contact pattern in the length of the tooth is indicated as toward the "heel" or "toe" of the ring gear ( Figure 114).

figure.caption: Figure 114. Ring Gear Toe and Heel

svcsubproc.para: Always check tooth contact patterns on the drive side of the gear teeth ( Figure 115).

svcsubproc.title: Tooth Contact Patterns of Conventional Hypoid and Generoid Hypoid Gear Sets

step1.para: Adjust the backlash of a new gear set to either .012 inch (.30 mm) or .015 inch (.38 mm) depending on the size of the ring gear. Adjust the backlash of an old gear set to the setting that was measured before the carrier was disassembled. Refer to CHECK RUNOUT OF RING GEAR.
Apply a marking compound to approximately 12 gear teeth of the ring gear. Rotate the ring gear so that the 12 gear teeth are next to the drive pinion ( Figure 116).

figure.caption: Figure 116. Apply Marking Compound to Gear Teeth of Ring Gear

step1.para: Rotate ring gear forward and backward so that the 12 gear teeth go past the drive pinion six times to get the contact patterns. Repeat if needed to get a more clear pattern.
Look at the contact patterns on the ring gear teeth. Compare the patterns to Figure 117 or Figure 120, Figure 118 or Figure 121, Figure 119 or Figure 122.

figure.caption: Figure 117. Conventional Gear Good Hand Rolled Pattern
Figure 120. Generoid Gear Good Hand Rolled Pattern

svcsubproc.title: The Location of Good Hand Rolled Contact Patterns

step1.para: New Conventional and Generoid Gear Sets - toward the toe of the gear tooth and in the center between the top and bottom of the tooth. See Figure 117 and Figure 120.

When the carrier is being operated, a good pattern will extend approximately the full length of the gear tooth. The top of the pattern will be near the top of the gear tooth ( Figure 123 and Figure 124).
The location of a good hand rolled contact pattern for an old gear set MUST match the wear pattern in the ring gear. The contact pattern will be smaller in area than the wear pattern.

If the contact patterns require adjustment, continue by following Step 1 to move the contact patterns between the top and bottom of the gear teeth. If the contact patterns are in the center of the gear teeth, continue by following Step 2.
Change the thickness of the shim pack under bearing cage to move the contact patterns between the top and bottom of the gear teeth. Use the following procedure.

note.para: A high contact pattern indicates that the drive pinion was not installed deep enough into the carrier. A low contact pattern indicates that the drive pinion was installed too deep in the carrier.

step2.para: Remove the drive pinion and bearing cage from the carrier. Refer to REMOVE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE FROM CARRIER.

To correct a high contact pattern, Figure 118 or Figure 121, decrease the thickness of the shim pack under the bearing cage. When you decrease the thickness of the shim pack, the drive pinion will move toward ring gear ( Figure 125).

To correct a low contact pattern, Figure 119 or Figure 122, increase the thickness of shim pack under the bearing cage. When you increase the thickness of the shim pack, the drive pinion will move away from the ring gear ( Figure 126).
Install the drive pinion, bearing cage and shims into the carrier. Refer to INSTALL THE DRIVE PINION, BEARING CAGE AND SHIM PACK INTO CARRIER.
Repeat Steps A to C until the contact patterns are in the center between the top and bottom of the gear teeth.

step1.para: Adjust backlash of the ring gear within specification range to move the contact patterns to the correct location in the length of the gear teeth.

step2.para: Decrease backlash to move the contact patterns toward the toe of the ring gear teeth ( Figure 127).
Increase backlash to move the contact patterns toward the heel of the ring gear teeth ( Figure 128).
Repeat Step 5, A to C and Step 6 until the contact patterns are at the correct location in the length of the gear teeth.

step1.para: Install cotter keys *, pins *, or lock plates * that hold the two bearing adjusting rings in position. Use the following procedures.

caution.para: If your carrier was built using cotter keys, lock the adjusting rings only with cotter keys. If your carrier was built using roll pins, reuse the roll pins or lock the adjusting rings with cotter keys. Do not force a roll pin into a cotter key hole.

step2.para: Cotter keys * - Install cotter keys between lugs of the adjusting ring and through the boss of the bearing cap. Bend the two ends of the cotter key around the boss ( Figure 129).

figure.caption: Figure 129. Install Cotter Keys, Pins, and Lock Plates

step2.para: Pins * - Install pin through boss of the bearing cap until the pin is between lugs of the adjusting ring. Use a drift and hammer to install the pin ( Figure 129).

Lock Plates * - Install lock plate on bearing cap so that the tab is between lugs of the adjusting ring. Install the two capscrews that hold the lock plate to the bearing cap. Tighten the capscrews to correct torque value. Refer to the TORQUE CHART, ( Figure 129).
